briefing.opening: Good morning. Welcome to today's climate briefing, February 2, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and Global Impacts
sections.content: The direct impacts of climate change are intensifying globally, with warning signs detected in various regions. Australia experienced an unprecedented heatwave approaching 50â„ƒ due to a 'heat dome' phenomenon [8], and ecological disruptions, such as penguins' breeding season starting earlier, have been confirmed [2]. Climate change is making it increasingly difficult to host the Winter Olympics [39, 56], and in Greenland, core climate change research has even been halted [42, 46]. Research suggests that some tropical land regions may experience stronger warming than anticipated [44], and impacts across daily life and industries, such as changes in chocolate prices and ingredient composition [45], are becoming a reality. Furthermore, the cumulative damage from greenhouse gas emissions is projected to reach 3,128 trillion KRW by 2100, emphasizing the urgent need for proactive responses [4].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Action and Challenges
sections.content: The international community continues various discussions and efforts to address climate change but simultaneously faces significant challenges. News has emerged that the US Trump administration has withdrawn from the Paris Agreement again, creating a rift in international climate change cooperation [5]. Nevertheless, environmental leaders are exploring ways to help communities combat climate change [40], and academic efforts continue, with Lehigh University researchers proposing new solutions to address climate change risks [48]. The fashion supply chain is preparing for how climate change will impact it in 2026 [43, 49], and the IMO-UNEP Innovation Forum is scheduled to discuss climate change response measures in the shipping sector [55]. The Egyptian Prime Minister has ordered the acceleration of coastal protection projects to counter climate change [57], and Seattle, USA, is supporting local climate action by investing in community-led projects affected by climate change [61].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Accelerating Domestic Carbon Neutrality and Policy Support
sections.content: Domestically, the efforts of the government and local authorities to achieve carbon neutrality goals are becoming more concrete. Gimcheon City [1, 3] and Cheonan City [9, 22, 25] are accelerating their response to climate change and carbon neutrality through organizational restructuring and setting key administrative goals. Chungnam Province is promoting and supporting carbon-neutral village communities, encouraging resident-led improvements in living environments [10, 13, 19], and Seoul City is supporting citizens' carbon neutrality practices by recruiting participants for its Eco-Mileage system [11]. Notably, the Korea Petroleum Management Institute broke ground on the Alternative Fuel Center, which will serve as a 'carbon neutrality outpost' [16], and Incheon Gyeyang-gu [17, 36] and Suncheon City [23] are leading the way in achieving carbon neutrality by expanding the supply of renewable energy and zero-emission vehicles. However, news that construction companies are struggling with the rapid pace of carbon neutrality suggests the need for careful consideration in the policy implementation process [15].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Renewable Energy Transition and Changes in the Domestic Energy Market
sections.content: The domestic energy market is undergoing significant changes, accelerating its transition to renewable energy. Efforts to expand renewable energy supply continue, with three onshore wind projects totaling 156MW selected [6]. In particular, the flexibility of the energy market is expected to increase as data centers receiving distributed energy are now allowed to directly purchase renewable energy (PPA), and district heating and distributed energy operators can also enter into renewable energy PPAs with users [31, 32, 34]. Korea's Sinan wind farm has been praised for showcasing the future of Korean energy [37], and Korea's top three battery companies are exploring a shift towards the ESS (Energy Storage System) sector in response to changes in the electric vehicle market [38]. However, the fact that onshore wind bids have been undersubscribed for three consecutive years indicates that additional policy support and institutional improvements are needed to expand renewable energy [35].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the severity of the climate crisis while also shedding light on various domestic and international efforts and challenges to overcome it. International cooperation and efficient implementation of domestic policies will become even more crucial for a sustainable future. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: Early termination of US EV subsidies... Struggling against Chinese companies' offensive in Europe. ESS demand surges in the US, where AI data centers are concentrated, leading to local mass production efforts. The performance slump in the domestic battery industry is deepening, driven by changes in EV subsidy policies in the US and Europe, coupled with an offensive from Chinese companies. South Korea's top three battery companies are now focusing on Energy Storage Systems (ESS) as a 'stable source of revenue' instead of electric vehicles.

summary.phenomenon: South Korea's top three battery companies are experiencing a performance slump in the US and European markets due to changes in EV subsidy policies and an offensive from Chinese companies.

summary.outlook: South Korea's top three battery companies are expected to focus on Energy Storage Systems (ESS) as a stable source of revenue, with surging demand in US regions concentrated with AI data centers, and will concentrate on local mass production instead of electric vehicles.

articles.original_title: South Wales council to buy and demolish homes prone to flooding
articles.description: Residents of 16 houses on Clydach Terrace in Ynysybwl express relief after repeated floods caused by climate crisisA row of homes in a village in south Wales is to be bought by a local authority and demolished as they can no longer be protected from flooding caused by the climate crisis.It will cost Rhondda Cynon Taf county borough council more than Â£2.5m to buy the 16 riverside properties, pay for legal costs and help to rehouse dozens of residents. summary.phenomenon: 16 riverside houses on Clydach Terrace in Ynysybwl, South Wales, can no longer be protected from repeated floods and will be purchased and demolished by the local authority. This process is expected to cost over Â£2.5 million.
summary.cause: The repeated floods in the area were caused by the climate crisis.
summary.outlook: The houses will be demolished, and dozens of residents will be supported to rehouse.
